data.title: Remove Basis::set_scale and Basis::set_rotation_* functions.
data.body:
Those functions were added in #8277 but they did more harm than good. They're subtle, don't do what people think and requires users to understand the non-uniqueness of polar decomposition. They ended up confusing people.

Until we store additional information enough to make a unique polar decomposition, these functions shouldn't be a part of Basis.

data.title: Disable -ffast-math for etc2comp
data.body:
Apparently -ffast-math generates incorrect code with recent versions of
GCC and Clang. The manual page for GCC warns about this possibility.

In my tests it doesn't actually appear to be measurably slower in this
case, and this is used in a batch process so it seems safe to disable
this.

This fixes #10758 and fixes #10070

data.title: Corrections to audio buffer size calculations
data.body:
Quick explanation: The number of channels wasn't being used in the total buffer_size. A second of sound has actually `sample rate * channels`, so our buffer_size must be equal to `buffer_frames * channels`, ref: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11048825/audio-sample-frequency-rely-on-channels


Long explanation: I found about this issue while working on the surround fixes.
The calculation for the buffer_size before this PR was:
```
buffer_size = closest_power_of_2(latency * mix_rate / 1000);
samples_in.resize(buffer_size);
buffer_frames = buffer_size / channels;
```
And the new one:
```
buffer_frames = closest_power_of_2(latency * mix_rate / 1000);
buffer_size = buffer_frames * channels;
samples_in.resize(buffer_size);
```
With for example latency=25, mix_rate=44100 and channels=6
Old one:
```
buffer_size = 25 * 44100 / 1000 = 1102 => closest_power_of_2(1102) = 1024
buffer_frames = 1024 / 6 = 170
```

New one:
```
buffer_frames = 25 * 44100 / 1000 = 1102 => closest_power_of_2(1102) = 1024
buffer_size = 1024 * 6 = 6144
```

So the old one gave a buffer size really small with 6 channels (it was also incorrect for 2 or 8 channels of course).

Note: I've modified only alsa, pulseaudio, osx, rtaudio and wasapi drivers, the rest needs to be checked/tested.

data.title: Fix joints collision exceptions, plus a bit more
data.body:
Fix 3D joint handling of collision exceptions, so that they lose effect when the joint is not valid in every case; also some redundant code removed.

Also avoid trying to create the joint when not neither body A nor body B are set.

Make 2D joints be handled like their 3D counterparts, which adds the fixes to them while also removing duplicated code.

__Sorry for the inverse porting logic; I made this originally for 2.1 not expecting just a cherry pick and some conflict solving would be enough for 3.0:__
(cherry picked from commit 4a98a59aa6810a679370e3664e89b3d83eb3d879)

~~__UPDATE:__ Commit added that fixes a removing-while-iterating issue.~~

__UPDATE:__ Commit added:

_Remove joint freeing logic from physics servers:_

Since joint resources are created by joint nodes and also they take care of freeing them, the physics server doesn't need to free bodies' joints explicitly.

The logic for clearing the constraints map/set is still relevant as there may be collision pairs and in their case its the server itself the one creating them and therefore releasing them.

May help with #10580.

data.title: Inconsistent script behavior for Buttons with `toggle_mode == true`
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**

any, current Godot master branch (e8b05ca996baa9819f55fc1d190a79d24906bde7)

**Issue description:**

The script function invoked when pressing a button with `toggle_mode == true` changes depending on its `action_mode`: if `action_mode == ACTION_MODE_BUTTON_PRESS` the `_pressed` function is called, when `action_mode == ACTION_MODE_BUTTON_RELEASE` the `_toggled` function is called instead.

It would seem more logical to me if the `_toggled` function was invoked in both cases.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Create a button, set it to toggle, define a GDScript function `_toggled`; depending on the action mode of the button the function will be invoked or not.

**Link to minimal example project:**

In the example project the left button works as expected, i.e., the text on the button changes whenever it is toggled. The right one has its action mode set to pressed, and only the background changes when it is toggled, not the text. When the `invoke_pressed` variable is set to `true` the right button changes its text to the values set by the `_pressed` function.

[Toggle Button.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1260872/Toggle.Button.zip)

data.title: Vector2/Vector3 shorthands
data.body: It would be handy to have shorthands for axis-aligned Vector2 and Vector3 values, like what is seen in Unity. Typing `Vector3.up` is a lot easier than `Vector3(0, 1, 0)`, and I'm pretty sure there are a few functions that require a common value like that (`move_and_slide()` is the one that comes to mind.) It comes up frequently enough that it becomes a little annoying to fully type out each time, and Unity set the precedent for this so a lot of people would also appreciate it. I know this is kind of an annoying request, but I think it's worth bringing up before 3.0 goes stable and compatibility-breaking changes like this can no longer be done.

data.title: Add multiple UI focus groups
data.body:
Supporting split screen multiplayer is right now quite tricky when it comes to the UI.
As of the current way focus works, only one element can be focused at any given time (so player specific UI in split screen is nearly impossible).
My proposal it the following:
- allow specifying a focus group on the viewport (default empty).
- focus inside the viewport is tied to the given group (i.e. if a node grab the focus it will not affect nodes inside viewports with a different group)
- UI elements that handle ui actions (`ui_*`) will handle `[GROUP]ui_*` (eg. `p1_ui_up`) instead, which means when assigning new focus groups you will have to add the appropriate UI actions to the `InputMap`.

I have implemented this method in `2.1` (see screenshot) but before doing more work to ready it for PR (on `master`) I'd like to hear opinions on this proposal (especially @reduz @akien-mga and other devs).
I thought about separating `focus_group` and `ui_action_group` but I'm not sure it makes sense. Additionally we might add a function `InputMap.add_group_ui_actions(String focus_group)` to add all the `[GROUP]ui_*` actions in bulk.

![focus_groups](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1687918/29822016-489f0190-8cca-11e7-8d06-5661d727c4c3.gif)


Thoughts? Suggestions?

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer mix node has unintuitive behavior
data.body:
Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):
Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot v3.0.alpha.custom_build.3ae1cff

I used this exclusively in 2D.

The mix node mixes between... a "default" state of the parameters to the ones in the animation. Take for example a simple rotation. If you make an animation of 360 deg. rotation, but having the first keyframe (at T0) be 90 deg. instead of 0. And say you have a second animation of horizontal looping motion, doesn't really matter. Now say we want to mix the horizontal movement with the rotation. The horizontal animation has no track for rotation. Then the mix node mixes from "default" state of the object (0 deg.) to the animation rotation.

I think a more useful mix node would have targets for each track of the mixed in animation. Or at least have a target animation for beginning and another for the mixed in. Or there should be a way to define the global "default" state to transition from with the mix node instead of assuming every parameter should mix in from 0 to the animation set parameters.

It's hard to explain but check the attached project, play with the edit slider on the mix node in animationtreeplayer and check the rotation animation in animationplayer. It's definitely not intuitive.

[godot-dbg.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1260079/godot-dbg.zip)

data.title: AnimationPlayer usability & improvements discussion
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot v3.0.alpha.custom_build.3ae1cff

I feel like the animation player is not intuitive at all. I propose to make it work like blender. Eg, things I found that don't make sense (some might be bugs):

1. some properties are modified even if the play cursors hasn't reached the keyframe. For example, take canvas modulate, and insert only one keyframe say at second 3 and change the color to something other than white (say red). Start the game with canvas modulate color at pure white. It turns out that the canvas modulate will be red immediately, even though there's no key to change it to red at 0! The position on the other hand behaves correctly, that is if you insert a key at second 3 and there's no other keyframe before that, then the object won't move until second 3 is reached. I've only tried a handful of properties but so far the only reasonable behavior is on position

2. if loop is turned on don't try to interpolate between last keyframe (before the animation finishes) and the first keyframe. Instead let's follow the blender way, so if I have a sprite that moves from left to right and only 2 keyframes, one at T0 and one at T1 and animation length of 2 seconds with loop turned on, I expect sprite to move only between T0 and T1. How it's implemented at the moment is, if loop is on, then there will be an interpolation between T1 and T0 as well (from second 1 and second 2). I think this isn't intuitive. Blender has some pretty good standards, if they do it that way they probably have a good reason why.

3. would be great if we could be able to type a number in the `Transition` panel instead of just relying on the mouse to move the easing around.

If you guys can think of anything else let the discussion begin :)
